name: Boeing 777-300ER
description: The Boeing 777-300ER (Extended Range) is the most popular and commercially successful variant of the 777 family, with over 800 deliveries. First delivered in 2004, it combines the stretched fuselage of the 777-300 with the raked wingtips and GE90-115B engines of the long-range variants. The 777-300ER offers both high passenger capacity (approximately 370 in three classes) and long range (7,370 nm), making it the backbone of many airlines' long-haul fleets and a common replacement for the Boeing 747-400.

zones.name: Cockpit
zones.description: The 777-300ER flight deck features the same fly-by-wire glass cockpit as all 777 variants, maintaining a common type rating across the family.

zones.name: Forward Galley
zones.description: The forward galley serving first and business class on long-haul intercontinental routes. Enhanced provisioning for extended flight times.

zones.name: Forward Lavatory
zones.description: Forward lavatories near the premium class cabin, often more spacious than economy lavatories.

zones.name: Forward Vestibule
zones.description: The forward entry vestibule at door 1L/1R, the primary boarding entrance for this flagship aircraft.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the forward cabin, housing first and business class window and aisle seats on the port side. Airlines compete fiercely with their premium products on this flagship long-haul aircraft.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the forward cabin, one of the twin aisles running through the wide-body 777-300ER. Crew use this aisle for premium cabin service on long-haul flights of up to 16 hours.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the forward cabin between the twin aisles. Many airlines feature fully enclosed first class suites with sliding doors in this section on their 777-300ER flagship routes.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the forward cabin, the starboard twin aisle providing a second path through the premium cabin for improved passenger flow on the most commercially successful wide-body twin.

zones.name: Forward Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the forward cabin on the starboard side, mirroring the left with first and business class seating designed for the competitive long-haul market.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the mid cabin, with premium economy and economy class seating on the port side. The combination of stretched fuselage and long range makes this a high-revenue section.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the expansive mid cabin. Twin aisles are essential for efficient meal service on long-haul flights serving hundreds of passengers in the largest cabin section.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the mid cabin between the twin aisles. Configured as 3 or 4 abreast in economy class, with personal entertainment screens featuring hundreds of options for flights of 10-16 hours.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the mid cabin, the starboard twin aisle through the largest cabin section. Essential for cabin crew to perform meal service efficiently on extended range flights.

zones.name: Mid Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the mid cabin on the starboard side. Window seats offer views of the distinctive raked wingtips that give the 777-300ER its improved fuel efficiency.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Seats
zones.description: The left seat section of the aft cabin on the world's most commercially successful wide-body twin. Airlines invest in cabin features like mood lighting and enhanced IFE throughout.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Left Aisle
zones.description: The left aisle of the aft cabin, continuing the port-side twin aisle toward the aft vestibule and galley on this long-haul flagship.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Center Seats
zones.description: The center seat section of the aft cabin between the twin aisles. Economy seats here feature personal IFE screens with USB charging for long-haul flights powered by the exclusive GE90-115B engines.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Aisle
zones.description: The right aisle of the aft cabin, the starboard twin aisle connecting to the aft vestibule on this record-setting twin-engine aircraft.

zones.name: Aft Cabin Right Seats
zones.description: The right seat section of the aft cabin on the starboard side. Last rows are nearest the aft galley provisioned for long-haul service on flights of up to 16 hours.

zones.name: Aft Vestibule
zones.description: The aft entry vestibule with the rear boarding doors.

zones.name: Aft Galley
zones.description: The aft galley provisioned for long-haul service, serving the large economy cabin on flights of 10-16 hours.

zones.name: Aft Lavatory
zones.description: Multiple aft lavatories serving the economy cabin on extended range long-haul flights.

zones.name: Forward Cargo Hold
zones.description: The forward lower-deck cargo hold beneath the forward cabin. The 777-300ER's cargo capacity supports both passenger baggage and belly freight revenue on long-haul routes, making it economically versatile.

zones.name: Aft Cargo Hold
zones.description: The aft lower-deck cargo hold beneath the mid and aft cabins. The stretched fuselage provides substantial cargo volume, and many airlines rely on the 777-300ER's belly freight capacity as a significant revenue stream on long-haul routes.

zones.name: Bulk Cargo Hold
zones.description: The bulk cargo compartment in the aft fuselage for loose-loaded baggage, mail, and small freight items. Essential for the diverse cargo needs of the 777-300ER's global route network.

zones.name: Cargo Access
zones.description: The cargo access area connecting the passenger deck to the lower cargo holds via a narrow passage near the nose gear bay. Used by ground crew for cargo operations at airports worldwide.

zones.name: Nose
zones.description: The nose section with weather radar antenna and forward avionics bay.

zones.name: Forward Fuselage
zones.description: The forward lower fuselage with the forward cargo hold and avionics bays.

zones.name: Mid Fuselage
zones.description: The center lower fuselage with the wing box carry-through structure, center fuel tank, and main gear wheel wells.

zones.name: Aft Fuselage
zones.description: The aft lower fuselage with the extended aft cargo hold and bulk cargo compartment.

zones.name: Tail
zones.description: The tail section with APU, tail skid, and empennage structures. The tail camera provides ground crew visibility of the long fuselage.

zones.name: Left Wing
zones.description: The port wing with raked wingtips extending the span to 64.8m for improved fuel efficiency. The raked tips reduce induced drag by up to 5%, critical for long-range economics.

zones.name: Right Wing
zones.description: The starboard wing with raked wingtips, matching the port wing configuration for maximum fuel efficiency.

zones.name: Left Engine
zones.description: The left GE90-115B engine, the exclusive powerplant for the 777-300ER. It produces 115,300 lbs of thrust and is one of the most powerful commercial jet engines ever produced.

zones.name: Right Engine
zones.description: The right GE90-115B engine. Unlike other 777 variants, the 777-300ER is exclusively powered by GE90-115B engines with no alternative engine option.

zones.name: Left Main Gear
zones.description: The left six-wheel bogie main gear rated for the 777-300ER's MTOW of 351,530 kg, the highest of any twin-engine commercial aircraft.

zones.name: Right Main Gear
zones.description: The right six-wheel bogie main gear, identical to the left.

zones.name: Nose Gear
zones.description: The steerable nose gear with dual wheels.

zones.name: Vertical Stabilizer
zones.description: The vertical stabilizer providing directional stability for the stretched fuselage at all speeds.

zones.name: Horizontal Stabilizer
zones.description: The trimmable horizontal stabilizer providing pitch stability and elevator mounting.

zones.name: APU
zones.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU essential for ETOPS operations on the 777-300ER's global route network.

components.name: Captain's Control Column
components.description: The captain's fly-by-wire control column. The 777-300ER shares a common type rating with all 777 variants.
components.interactionText: Grasp the captain's yoke on the most commercially successful wide-body twin-engine aircraft in aviation history.

components.name: First Officer's Control Column
components.description: The first officer's fly-by-wire control column.
components.interactionText: The first officer's yoke provides independent fly-by-wire authority.

components.name: Throttle Quadrant
components.description: Twin thrust levers for the GE90-115B engines, the exclusive powerplant for this variant.
components.interactionText: Command the GE90-115B engines. The 777-300ER is the only 777 variant with a single engine option.

components.name: Rudder Pedals
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder pedals with speed-dependent authority limiting.
components.interactionText: Rudder pedals with automatic authority reduction at higher speeds. Critical for crosswind landings on the long fuselage.

components.name: Primary Flight Display (PFD)
components.description: Large-format PFD with full flight data integration on high-resolution LCD.
components.interactionText: The PFD displays attitude, speeds, altitude, and flight mode annunciations for global route operations.

components.name: Navigation Display (ND)
components.description: Navigation display for managing the 777-300ER's extensive global route network.
components.interactionText: View routes connecting major global hubs. The 777-300ER operates on every continent except Antarctica.

components.name: Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System
components.description: EICAS monitoring both GE90-115B engines and all aircraft systems.
components.interactionText: Monitor the GE90-115B engine parameters. The tail camera display helps with ground maneuvering the long fuselage.

components.name: Overhead Panel
components.description: Systems control panel shared across all 777 variants through the common type rating.
components.interactionText: The overhead panel follows the dark cockpit philosophy. In normal operations, no lights are illuminated.

components.name: Mode Control Panel (MCP)
components.description: Autopilot interface for managing long-haul flight profiles including step climbs and cost-index optimization.
components.interactionText: Program step climbs and speed targets for optimal fuel burn on long-haul routes up to 16 hours.

components.name: Flight Management Computer (FMC)
components.description: Triple-redundant FMC handling complex routing for the 777-300ER's global network including ETOPS, polar, and oceanic operations.
components.interactionText: Program the most commercially successful wide-body routes in aviation. The FMC handles ETOPS-330, polar routes, and oceanic tracks.

components.name: Forward Left Entry Door (1L)
components.description: The main wide-body boarding door. The 777-300ER has five door pairs for evacuation certification.
components.interactionText: The main boarding door for the world's most popular wide-body twin. Five door pairs ensure rapid evacuation.

components.name: Aft Left Entry Door (5L)
components.description: The aft left entry door. Additional door pairs required by the stretched fuselage length.
components.interactionText: The aft door enables rear boarding for faster turnaround on this high-utilization aircraft.

components.name: Forward Galley Unit
components.description: The premium class forward galley supporting first and business class on flagship intercontinental routes.
components.interactionText: The forward galley supports the premium catering that airlines use to differentiate their 777-300ER service.

components.name: Aft Galley Unit
components.description: The aft economy galley scaled for the 777-300ER's high passenger capacity on long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: The enlarged aft galley provisions for long-haul service to over 300 economy passengers.

components.name: Overhead Storage Bins
components.description: Wide-body overhead bins with Boeing's latest cabin interior design spanning the extended fuselage.
components.interactionText: Three rows of bins provide storage for the 777-300ER's typical 350+ passengers.

components.name: Row 1 First Class Suites
components.description: First class suites representing the pinnacle of airline product on the most prestigious long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Airlines compete fiercely with their first class product on the 777-300ER. Suites feature doors, lie-flat beds, and dining tables.

components.name: Forward Cabin First/Business Class Seats
components.description: Premium seating in the forward cabin of the 777-300ER, the world's most popular long-range wide-body. Airlines typically configure this section with first class suites followed by business class. Many carriers feature fully enclosed first class suites with sliding doors.
components.interactionText: Sit in the premium forward cabin of the 777-300ER. This is where airlines showcase their finest products. Some first class suites feature closing doors, personal minibars, and seats that convert to full-length beds. Business class follows with lie-flat seats and direct aisle access.

components.name: Mid Cabin Premium Economy Seats
components.description: The front of the mid cabin on the 777-300ER often features premium economy class, a cabin between business and economy. These seats offer 38-inch pitch, wider seats, larger screens, and enhanced meal service. The 777-300ER's popularity on long-haul routes makes premium economy especially valued.
components.interactionText: Sit in a premium economy seat. Notice the extra legroom, wider seat, and larger entertainment screen compared to standard economy. The dedicated cabin offers a middle ground between business and economy class service.

components.name: Mid Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Standard economy seats in the rear portion of the 777-300ER's mid cabin. Configured in 3-3-3 or 3-4-3 layout depending on the airline. Each seat features a personal entertainment screen with hundreds of movie and TV options for long-haul flights powered by the GE90-115B engines.
components.interactionText: Sit in a mid cabin economy seat on the world's most popular long-range twin. The twin aisles keep things moving during meal service. Check the seatback entertainment, USB port, and personal reading light.

components.name: Aft Cabin Economy Seats
components.description: Economy seats in the aft cabin of the 777-300ER. This section is near the massive GE90-115B engines, the most powerful jet engines ever built. The aft cabin is the last to board and first served on many airlines. The retractable tail skid beneath protects the stretched fuselage during takeoff rotation.
components.interactionText: Sit in an aft seat on the 777-300ER. The powerful GE90-115B engines nearby can produce over 115,000 pounds of thrust each. The rear galley is just behind, and the tail camera feed may be available on your screen. Check the overhead bin and safety card.

components.name: Passenger Cabin Window
components.description: Standard 777 cabin windows along the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: The 777 cabin windows are among the largest in commercial aviation.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins running along the left side of the forward cabin above the port-side premium class seats.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the forward cabin. Premium cabin bins on the 777-300ER are often larger to accommodate suit bags and coats for long-haul travelers.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins running along the right side of the forward cabin above the starboard-side premium seats.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the forward cabin. Airlines differentiate their 777-300ER product with the latest Boeing Sky Interior overhead bins.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the expansive mid cabin, serving hundreds of economy passengers on long-haul flights.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the mid cabin. The 777-300ER's extended mid section has generous bin space for long-haul carry-on luggage.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the mid cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the mid cabin. Boeing's Sky Interior bins pivot down for easier access on this popular long-haul aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the left side of the aft cabin in the rear section of the stretched fuselage.
components.interactionText: Open the left overhead bin in the aft cabin. Rear bins sometimes have more space available as forward bins fill first during boarding.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Overhead Bins
components.description: Overhead storage bins along the right side of the aft cabin on the starboard side.
components.interactionText: Open the right overhead bin in the aft cabin. The 777-300ER's cabin provides bin storage for over 350 passengers on typical long-haul configurations.

components.name: Forward Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the forward cabin, offering views from the premium class section on flagship long-haul routes.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the forward cabin. From first or business class on this flagship aircraft, enjoy the view on routes spanning the globe.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the forward cabin on the starboard side of the most commercially successful wide-body twin.
components.interactionText: Look through the right window in the forward premium cabin. The 777's windows are among the largest in commercial aviation at 15 inches tall.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the mid cabin, positioned over the wing area with views of the port engine and the distinctive raked wingtips.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the mid cabin. You can see the port wing with its distinctive raked wingtip that gives the 777-300ER improved fuel efficiency.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the mid cabin with views of the starboard raked wingtip and GE90-115B engine.
components.interactionText: Look through the right window over the wing. You can see the starboard GE90-115B engine and the raked wingtip that extends the span to 64.8 meters.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Window
components.description: A passenger window on the left side of the aft cabin, behind the wing trailing edge on this long-range flagship.
components.interactionText: Look through the left window in the aft cabin. Behind the wing, you have a clear view of the flaps deploying during approach after a long-haul flight.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window
components.description: A passenger window on the right side of the aft cabin on the starboard side of this record-setting twin-engine aircraft.
components.interactionText: Look through the right aft window. From this far back on the stretched fuselage, the wing trailing edge and flap tracks are visible during landing configuration.

components.name: Forward Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the forward cabin near the over-wing emergency exit. Provides extra legroom due to exit door clearance requirements.
components.interactionText: Sit in the forward exit row seat on the left. Extra legroom here comes with the responsibility to assist in an emergency on this high-capacity aircraft.

components.name: Forward Cabin Right Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side of the forward cabin in first or business class, offering views on the world's most popular long-haul wide-body.
components.interactionText: Sit in a forward cabin window seat on the starboard side. First and business class window seats on the 777-300ER are among the most sought-after in commercial aviation.

components.name: Forward Cabin Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the forward cabin between the twin aisles. On the 777-300ER, some airlines configure center first class suites as companion seats with shared social areas.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the forward cabin between the twin aisles. Some 777-300ER first class products feature center companion suites with a shared dining table.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the mid cabin at the over-wing emergency exit. The most sought-after economy seat for its generous legroom on long-haul flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the mid cabin exit row on the left side. On long-haul 777-300ER flights of up to 16 hours, the extra legroom at the exit row is especially valued.

components.name: Mid Cabin Exit Row Right Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the right side of the mid cabin at the over-wing emergency exit, mirroring the left side with extra legroom.
components.interactionText: Sit in the mid cabin exit row on the right. You can see the raked wingtip through the large exit window. Some airlines charge a premium for this seat on long-haul routes.

components.name: Mid Cabin Front Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the front of the mid cabin. In 3-4-3 configuration, center seats are between the twin aisles with personal entertainment for long-haul flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the mid cabin front section. In high-density 3-4-3 layout, the center block has four seats. Each features a personal screen for the long-haul journey.

components.name: Mid Cabin Left Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the left side of the mid cabin over the wing, offering views of the port GE90-115B engine and the wing with raked wingtips.
components.interactionText: Sit at the left window in the mid cabin. From here you can watch the slats and flaps deploy on the port wing and see the raked wingtip during approach.

components.name: Mid Cabin Rear Center Seat
components.description: A center section seat in the rear of the expansive mid cabin on the world's most popular long-range wide-body twin.
components.interactionText: Sit in the center of the rear mid cabin. You are in the heart of the 777-300ER's economy section on the backbone aircraft of many long-haul fleets.

components.name: Mid Cabin Right Window Rear Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side toward the rear of the mid cabin, behind the wing trailing edge with unobstructed views.
components.interactionText: Sit at the right window in the rear mid cabin. Behind the wing, you have an unobstructed view of the sky on your long-haul journey.

components.name: Aft Cabin Exit Row Left Seat
components.description: An exit row seat on the left side of the aft cabin near the aft emergency exit, with extra legroom valued on long-haul flights.
components.interactionText: Sit in the aft cabin exit row on the left. Extra legroom and proximity to the aft exit make this especially desirable on the 777-300ER's long-haul routes.

components.name: Aft Cabin Right Window Seat
components.description: A window seat on the right side of the aft cabin, toward the rear of the stretched fuselage near the powerful GE90-115B engines.
components.interactionText: Sit at the right window in the aft cabin. You can hear the GE90-115B engines nearby, the most powerful jet engines ever built for a commercial aircraft.

components.name: Aft Cabin Last Row Center Seat
components.description: The last row center seat in the aft cabin, closest to the aft galley provisioned for long-haul service. Often has limited recline due to the bulkhead behind.
components.interactionText: Sit in the very last row of the 777-300ER. The aft galley with long-haul provisions is directly behind. Seats here may not recline fully but you are first to be served.

components.name: Aft Cabin Left Rear Seat
components.description: A left-side seat near the rear of the aft cabin, close to the aft lavatories and galley on this long-haul flagship.
components.interactionText: Sit on the left side near the back of the aft cabin. The aft lavatories are just a few rows behind, convenient on long-haul flights of up to 16 hours.

components.name: Forward Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 unit load device containers in the forward cargo hold. The 777-300ER's belly freight capacity is a significant revenue stream for airlines on long-haul routes, carrying both passenger baggage and commercial freight.
components.interactionText: Rows of LD3 containers fill the forward cargo hold. The 777-300ER's belly freight capacity makes it economically versatile, carrying revenue cargo alongside passenger baggage.

components.name: Forward Cargo Net and Barrier
components.description: Cargo nets and barriers in the forward hold securing LD3 containers during long-haul flights. Load restraint is critical for maintaining aircraft center of gravity on routes of up to 16 hours.
components.interactionText: Cargo nets stretch across the forward hold, securing containers against turbulence on long-haul flights. Proper restraint is critical for flight safety over oceans.

components.name: Forward Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The hydraulic cargo door mechanism for the forward lower cargo hold. The door opens outward and upward for ground loading of LD3 containers at airports worldwide.
components.interactionText: The forward cargo door mechanism uses hydraulic actuators. Multiple safety latches prevent in-flight opening. The door warning system is monitored on EICAS.

components.name: Aft Cargo LD3 Containers
components.description: LD3 containers in the aft cargo hold, the largest cargo compartment on the 777-300ER. Airlines on competitive long-haul routes rely on this hold for significant belly freight revenue.
components.interactionText: The aft cargo hold is packed with LD3 containers. The 777-300ER's combination of passenger capacity and cargo volume makes it the most commercially successful wide-body twin.

components.name: Aft Cargo Net and Barrier
components.description: Cargo nets and barriers in the aft hold securing containers for the 777-300ER's extended range flights across oceans and continents.
components.interactionText: Heavy-duty cargo nets secure the aft hold containers. On ETOPS routes over oceans, proper cargo restraint is part of the dispatch requirements.

components.name: Aft Cargo Door Mechanism
components.description: The hydraulic cargo door mechanism for the aft lower cargo hold, providing access to the largest cargo compartment on the most commercially successful wide-body twin.
components.interactionText: The aft cargo door opens to reveal the 777-300ER's spacious aft hold. Ground loaders use powered conveyor systems to position LD3 containers at airports worldwide.

components.name: Bulk Cargo Compartment
components.description: The bulk cargo compartment in the aft fuselage for loose-loaded baggage, mail, and small freight. Handles diverse cargo needs on the 777-300ER's global route network.
components.interactionText: The bulk cargo area holds loose baggage and small freight. Items are hand-loaded through a smaller door, separate from the main containerized cargo doors.

components.name: Left GE90-115B Engine
components.description: The left GE90-115B, the exclusive engine for the 777-300ER. The 134-inch fan with 22 composite blades produces 115,300 lbs of thrust.
components.interactionText: The GE90-115B is the only engine option for the 777-300ER. Its reliability has made the aircraft the benchmark for twin-engine long-haul operations.

components.name: Right GE90-115B Engine
components.description: The right GE90-115B engine. The pair delivers the combined thrust needed for the 777-300ER's 351,530 kg MTOW.
components.interactionText: Each GE90-115B uses FADEC to optimize engine performance automatically across all flight conditions.

components.name: Nose Landing Gear Assembly
components.description: The nose gear with dual wheels for the heaviest twin-engine commercial aircraft.
components.interactionText: The nose gear steers the 73.9-meter long aircraft during ground operations at airports worldwide.

components.name: Left Main Landing Gear
components.description: The left six-wheel bogie rated for 351,530 kg MTOW, the highest of any twin-engine aircraft ever built.
components.interactionText: The main gear handles the enormous weight of the fully fueled 777-300ER. Semi-levered design prevents tail strikes.

components.name: Right Main Landing Gear
components.description: The right six-wheel bogie, identical to the left.
components.interactionText: Six wheels per bogie distribute the world record twin-engine MTOW across the runway surface.

components.name: Left Aileron
components.description: The left fly-by-wire aileron on the raked-wingtip wing.
components.interactionText: The aileron sits inboard of the raked wingtips that give the 777-300ER its distinctive wing profile.

components.name: Right Aileron
components.description: The right fly-by-wire aileron on the extended-span wing.
components.interactionText: The right aileron works opposite to the left for roll control on the 64.8m wingspan.

components.name: Left Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon providing high-lift capability at the 777-300ER's record MTOW.
components.interactionText: Fowler flaps extend on tracks to provide the lift needed at the highest MTOW of any twin-engine aircraft.

components.name: Right Trailing Edge Flaps
components.description: Single-slotted Fowler flaps and flaperon on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Right flaps deploy symmetrically for balanced lift augmentation.

components.name: Left Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the left wing with raked wingtips.
components.interactionText: Full-span slats work with the raked wingtips for optimal low-speed performance.

components.name: Right Leading Edge Slats
components.description: Full-span leading edge slats on the right wing.
components.interactionText: Symmetric slat deployment maintains balanced lift during configuration changes.

components.name: Elevator
components.description: Fly-by-wire elevators providing pitch authority for the stretched fuselage. Careful rotation technique required to avoid tail strikes.
components.interactionText: Elevator pitch control must be managed carefully during rotation. The tail camera assists with ground proximity awareness.

components.name: Rudder
components.description: Fly-by-wire rudder with triple-redundant hydraulic actuators for the flagship 777 variant.
components.interactionText: Triple-redundant rudder actuators provide the reliability needed for ETOPS-330 global operations.

components.name: Wing Spoilers / Speed Brakes
components.description: Fly-by-wire spoiler panels essential for descent management and ground stopping performance.
components.interactionText: Spoilers manage descent rate and provide essential ground stopping performance for the heaviest twin-engine aircraft.

components.name: Tail Skid
components.description: The retractable tail skid protecting the stretched fuselage from tail strikes during takeoff rotation.
components.interactionText: The tail skid protects the aft fuselage if the pilot over-rotates during takeoff. A tail camera also aids awareness.

components.name: Pitot Tubes
components.description: Multiple pitot probes on the forward fuselage for airspeed measurement with redundancy.
components.interactionText: Heated pitot probes provide redundant airspeed data to the air data computers.

components.name: Weather Radar Antenna
components.description: Advanced weather radar with predictive windshear capability for global route operations.
components.interactionText: The weather radar provides long-range storm detection essential for oceanic and intercontinental route planning.

components.name: APU Exhaust
components.description: The Honeywell 331-500 APU required for ETOPS dispatch on the 777-300ER's global route network.
components.interactionText: The APU provides ground power and is required serviceable for ETOPS operations across the world's oceans.

controlSurfaces.name: Ailerons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke turned: fly-by-wire commands aileron deflection on the raked-wingtip wings.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Roll control with envelope protection. The raked wingtips improve aerodynamic efficiency and roll damping.

controlSurfaces.name: Elevator
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Yoke pulled back: elevators up. Pushed forward: elevators down.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Pitch control requires careful technique on the stretched fuselage. The tail camera and tail skid provide safety margins.

controlSurfaces.name: Rudder
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Left pedal: rudder left. Right pedal: rudder right. Speed-dependent authority limiting.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Yaw control for coordinated flight, crosswinds, and single-engine ETOPS scenarios on global operations.

controlSurfaces.name: Trailing Edge Flaps
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flap lever positions: UP, 1, 5, 15, 20, 25, 30. Fowler flaps extend on tracks.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Critical lift augmentation for the heaviest twin-engine MTOW in commercial aviation history.

controlSurfaces.name: Leading Edge Slats
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Full-span slats deploy automatically with flap selection.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Slats increase maximum angle of attack for safe approach speeds at the 777-300ER's high weights.

controlSurfaces.name: Spoilers / Speed Brakes
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Speedbrake lever: symmetric deployment. Roll input: asymmetric deployment.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Speed brakes manage descent rate. Ground spoilers are critical for stopping the heaviest twin-engine aircraft.

controlSurfaces.name: Flaperons
controlSurfaces.movementDescription: Flaperons droop with flap extension and deflect differentially for roll.
controlSurfaces.flightEffect: Combined flap and aileron function optimized for the raked-wingtip wing design on the most successful 777 variant.
